subject: A Level English Language and Literature (EMC)
group_title: Section A – Reading as a writer
group_instructions: Choose one of the following two questions and answer in relation to the text that you have studied. You should spend about 1 hour on this section.
question_text:
In what ways does the writer of your text use time?

You should range across the text to explore how time is manipulated, the role it plays in the novel as a whole, and the broader generic context.
scenario:
Charlotte Brontë: Jane Eyre
F Scott Fitzgerald: The Great Gatsby
Chinua Achebe: Things Fall Apart
Arundhati Roy: The God of Small Things
Ian McEwan: Atonement
Jhumpa Lahiri: The Namesake
memo_question_text: In what ways does the writer of your text use time?
marker_instruction: A response that does not address any one of the three assessment objectives (AO1, AO2, AO3) targeted cannot achieve all of the marks in the given level. Use 'best fit' to locate the level descriptor.
essay_structure: {"conclusion": ["Summarize how the manipulation of time serves the novel’s themes and structural integrity."], "introduction": ["Answers should range across the text to explore how time is manipulated.", "Identify the role time plays in the novel as a whole and the broader generic context."], "body_sections": [{"points": ["Time passes from Jane aged 10 to Jane established in her marriage to Rochester.", "Autobiographical voice (Bildungsroman) comments on what the child saw compared with what the woman later judged.", "Rites of passage novel structure moving from early years to time present.", "Periods of Jane’s life are individuated sharply to illustrate stages on her spiritual journey.", "Sober narrator uses distance of time to contrast the 'sanguine, brilliant, careless, romping child' with the adult self."], "sub_topic": "Jane Eyre (AO2 and AO1)"}, {"points": ["Historical novel covering fifteen years of the pre-Victorian period.", "Abuses (e.g. Mr Brocklehurst) are fixed in the near past and viewed as trauma.", "Gothic elements reflect Romanticism and the Gothic novel tradition.", "Transcendence of contemporary stereotypes through romance."], "sub_topic": "Jane Eyre (AO3)"}, {"points": ["Narrator Nick tells his story consecutively but with numerous loops in time for backstory.", "Gatsby lives partly in the past and is reconstructing it in time present.", "Flashes of a simpler Gatsby at earlier periods (e.g. with Dan Cody or diary entry).", "Time is telescoped in final pages reaching from mid-western settlers to first Dutchmen.", "Prose conjures earlier periods; the long summer serves as a temporal backdrop."], "sub_topic": "The Great Gatsby (AO2 and AO1)"}, {"points": ["Set during Prohibition, after WWI, with an atmosphere of impending catastrophe.", "Characters like Tom and Daisy are caught in the present; Gatsby looks back to innocence.", "Suggestion that time can be cheated temporarily by 'successful gestures'."], "sub_topic": "The Great Gatsby (AO3)"}, {"points": ["Timeframe shielded in the first section; time counted in seasons and rituals.", "Life seen as a series of transition rites bringing one nearer to ancestors.", "Simple prose communicates tragedy and joy; proverbs and fables are integrated.", "History enters in second and third sections with missionaries and colonisers.", "Novel as a fable about the impossibility of dragging traditional culture into the 20th century in one generation."], "sub_topic": "Things Fall Apart (AO2 and AO1)"}, {"points": ["Reflects history of missionaries in Nigeria (1860s) and colonial rule (1880s).", "Okonkwo's conversion to Christianity contrasted with indigenous creeds of honour-killing.", "District Commissioner's 'pacifying' processes at the end."], "sub_topic": "Things Fall Apart (AO3)"}, {"points": ["Rejection of colonial memories for post-colonial India's contemporary problems.", "Non-linear handling of time compresses and transcends history.", "Cultural setting dwarfs characters; Rahel's development as focaliser holds events at micro-level.", "Disjointed events in coherent order mirror complex cultural problems."], "sub_topic": "The God of Small Things (AO1 and AO2)"}, {"points": ["Timeframe moves between 1969 (separation) and 1993 (reunion).", "Irregular unfolding of memories concentrates story on the twins.", "Sense of time passing brought to a standstill."], "sub_topic": "The God of Small Things (AO3)"}, {"points": ["Discrete sections: historical sequences (1935, 1940), wish-fulfilment (WWII), and coda (1999).", "Briony's control highlights the responsibilities of the fiction writer.", "Wartime sections use terse prose ('bleakest realism').", "Opening pages use flourishing symbolism derived from a 'teenage novella'."], "sub_topic": "Atonement (AO1 and AO2)"}, {"points": ["Class tensions (Robbie Turner vs upper-class) reminiscent of Victorian/Edwardian novels.", "Graphic handling of retreat from Dunkirk and wartime nursing.", "Embodiment of desperate moral choices of wartime."], "sub_topic": "Atonement (AO3)"}, {"points": ["Journey narrative with biographical format; hero as focaliser.", "Free indirect discourse splices in parents' opinions.", "Gogol's name anxieties form rites of passage and structure the book.", "Precise dates matter in family history.", "Exploration of immigrant lives built on changing attitudes over years."], "sub_topic": "The Namesake (AO1 and AO2)"}, {"points": ["Background of American history (Vietnam to Millennium) and recreational drugs.", "Concentration on family ties over professional interests.", "Distance between Indian culture and the American 'world'."], "sub_topic": "The Namesake (AO3)"}]}
memo_notes: Assessment Objectives: AO2 (6%), AO1 (5%), AO3 (5%). Total 16%. Dominant AO is AO2.

subject: A Level English Language and Literature (EMC)
group_title: Section A – Reading as a writer
group_instructions: Choose one of the following two questions and answer in relation to the text that you have studied. You should spend about 1 hour on this section.
question_text:
How does the writer of your text use contrasts?

You should range across the text to explore how contrasts are created, the role they play in the novel as a whole, and the broader generic context.
scenario:
Charlotte Brontë: Jane Eyre
F Scott Fitzgerald: The Great Gatsby
Chinua Achebe: Things Fall Apart
Arundhati Roy: The God of Small Things
Ian McEwan: Atonement
Jhumpa Lahiri: The Namesake
memo_question_text: How does the writer of your text use contrasts?
marker_instruction: A response that does not address any one of the three assessment objectives (AO1, AO2, AO3) targeted cannot achieve all of the marks in the given level.
essay_structure: {"conclusion": ["Evaluate how contrasts sharpen the novel's themes or characterizations."], "introduction": ["Explore how contrasts are created and the role they play in the novel as a whole.", "Relate contrasts to the broader generic context."], "body_sections": [{"points": ["Uncompromising judgements of a child’s world at Lowood vs Brocklehurst’s lifestyle.", "Spirituality of Helen Burns contrasted with St John Rivers.", "Contrasts between Gothic imaginings and terrible truths.", "Marriage offers from Rivers and Rochester as contrasting romance formats.", "Stylistic use of oxymorons (e.g. 'pure gold, with a steely point of agony')."], "sub_topic": "Jane Eyre (AO2 and AO1)"}, {"points": ["Male freedom vs Jane’s Puritanical self-restraint.", "Gentility of the governess vs grand airs of the Ingrams.", "Jane’s integrity vs arbitrary authority figures.", "Worldly vs spiritual callings in liberal Victorian evangelicalism."], "sub_topic": "Jane Eyre (AO3)"}, {"points": ["Eastern backgrounds vs New York metropolitan playground.", "Valley of Ashes (poverty/decrepitude) vs glamour of Gatsby’s parties.", "Gatsby as a walking contradiction (Platonic essence vs bootlegger).", "Large parties as 'loneliest places'.", "Daisy's gleam vs struggles of the poor (social satire)."], "sub_topic": "The Great Gatsby (AO2 and AO1)"}, {"points": ["Roaring twenties cynical song-lyrics vs grinding poverty of immigrants.", "Moral reform/Prohibition vs fortunes made by breaking the law."], "sub_topic": "The Great Gatsby (AO3)"}, {"points": ["Linguistic contrasts between Okonkwo’s feelings and simple narrative language.", "Gender difference: male brutality vs serene domestic village life.", "Oral culture (folk-tales) vs imposed written English (bureaucrats/missionaries).", "Tribal needs vs colonial designs."], "sub_topic": "Things Fall Apart (AO2 and AO1)"}, {"points": ["Decision to write in English vs Nigerian dialect (linguistic paradox).", "English as a tool that commemorates the process of colonisation."], "sub_topic": "Things Fall Apart (AO3)"}, {"points": ["Free prose/time tricks vs robust traditional 'love laws'.", "Malayalam dialect vs English (lingua franca).", "Cultural conflicts: Catholic asceticism, communism, and the caste system.", "Acceptance of 'Untouchable' status vs individual desire."], "sub_topic": "The God of Small Things (AO1 and AO2)"}, {"points": ["Linguistic registers (child talk vs old English hegemony).", "Lush descriptions of scent/sound/colour vs small tragedies (epic vs microcosmic)."], "sub_topic": "The God of Small Things (AO3)"}, {"points": ["Pallid prose of Section 1 vs fierce reportage of later sections.", "Tensions between the real world of action and metafictional aesthetic motives.", "Cyril Connolly's 'crystalline present moment' vs Robbie’s fatal progress in Dunkirk.", "Briony's life as a writer vs the 'huge fact of death'."], "sub_topic": "Atonement (AO1 and AO2)"}, {"points": ["Briony’s successful fiction vs her tangle of shame and frustration.", "Privileged upbringing vs a war where 'everyone was guilty and no-one was'."], "sub_topic": "Atonement (AO3)"}, {"points": ["Rewards and difficulties of multiculturalism.", "Unambitious, 'arms-length' prose vs complex identity shifts.", "Ancestral culture vs American pop culture and sexual revolution.", "Setting contrasts: sub-continental scale (India) vs architectural décor of living spaces."], "sub_topic": "The Namesake (AO1 and AO2)"}, {"points": ["Liberalisation in up-market American life vs Bengali family culture.", "Gogol’s name change compared to 'revolutionaries and transvestites'."], "sub_topic": "The Namesake (AO3)"}]}

subject: A Level English Language and Literature (EMC)
group_title: Section B – Writing as a reader
group_instructions: Answer Question 3 and Question 4 in this section. You have a choice of task in Question 3. It is recommended that you spend about 40 minutes on Question 3 and 20 minutes on Question 4.
question_text:
Choose one of the storylines below to develop as the opening of a narrative.

Write your narrative, making your own choices about the story’s starting point and linguistic techniques. You are writing the opening to a narrative, and can use any one of the bullet points as the beginning of your story. You are not expected to write the full story and you are not required to use all six bullet points.

You should write approximately 500 words.
scenario:
Either
Storyline 1
• A young bride woke up one morning.
• Her body ached; her mouth was dry; she struggled to get out of bed.
• When she looked in the mirror, she found she had aged fifty years.
• ‘My memories!’ she said. ‘They’ve been taken.’
• She began to hunt up and down the land for whoever looked as she had once looked.
• One day, long afterwards, she finally found what she had been searching for.

Or
Storyline 2
• It is early morning and the temperature is just above zero.
• A lorry driver spots a moving shape by the side of the dual carriageway.
• The driver pulls over and sees that the shape is a child about three years old.
• Barefoot, the child is carrying a pair of shoes.
• The lorry driver asks where the child’s parents are.
• The child asks the driver for help putting on the shoes.
memo_question_text: Choose one of the storylines below to develop as the opening of a narrative.
marker_instruction: A response that does not address one of the two assessment objectives (AO5, AO2) targeted cannot achieve all of the marks in the given level. Candidates should write approximately 500 words. Mark the opening only; they are not required to write the full story.
essay_structure: {"conclusion": ["Candidates will use techniques drawn from their study in Section 1 (dialogue, description, imagery, narrative voice, time handling)."], "introduction": ["Write the opening to a narrative making your own choices about starting point and linguistic techniques.", "Use any one of the provided bullet points (not all six required)."], "body_sections": [{"points": ["AO5: Demonstrate expertise and creativity in English to create an effective opening.", "AO5: Show high degree of control over chosen techniques.", "AO2: Demonstrate sophisticated awareness of how meanings are shaped in narrative texts."], "sub_topic": "High-Level Response (Levels 4-6)"}, {"points": ["AO5: Show some ability to shape the opening beyond basic storytelling.", "AO2: Show some awareness of the ways in which meanings are shaped in narrative texts."], "sub_topic": "Lower-Level Response (Levels 1-3)"}]}
memo_notes: Assessment Objectives: AO5 (7%), AO2 (2%). Total 9%. Dominant AO is AO5.

subject: A Level English Language and Literature (EMC)
group_title: Section B – Writing as a reader
group_instructions: Answer Question 3 and Question 4 in this section. It is recommended that you spend about 40 minutes on Question 3 and 20 minutes on Question 4.
question_text: Outline the key narrative and linguistic techniques you have used in your writing for Question 3. You should write approximately 250 words.
memo_question_text: Outline the key narrative and linguistic techniques you have used in your writing for Question 3.
marker_instruction: A response that does not address one of the two assessment objectives (AO1, AO2) targeted cannot achieve all of the marks in the given level. Candidates should write approximately 250 words.
essay_structure: {"conclusion": ["Candidates are not expected to write about connections to studied texts, but rather their own adopted narrative concepts."], "introduction": ["Explain and analyse the narrative techniques used in the creative writing for Q3."], "body_sections": [{"points": ["AO1: Apply concepts and methods from study using relevant terminology.", "AO1: Use coherent written expression to convincingly show how techniques were used.", "AO2: Effectively and convincingly analyse how meanings are shaped in the Q3 response."], "sub_topic": "High-Level Response (Levels 4-6)"}, {"points": ["AO1: Identify some concepts and methods with some terminology.", "AO2: Describe some ways in which meanings have been shaped."], "sub_topic": "Lower-Level Response (Levels 1-3)"}]}
memo_notes: Assessment Objectives: AO1 (4%), AO2 (3%). Total 7%. Dominant AO is AO1.
